paragraphs.text: Cambridge Executive Leadership Programme
Media Strategy & Campaign Plan
Construct Digital | December 2025
Campaign Overview
Strategic context and objectives
Strategic Challenge
NUS Executive Education must compete for senior executive mindshare across 9 Asia-Pacific markets
Competing against global institutions (INSEAD, IMD, London Business School) and regional players
Cambridge Programme value: Stanford-NUS faculty caliber and strategic leadership content
Market context: Executives prioritize ROI-driven programmes amid economic uncertainty and AI disruption
Core Objective
Generate 62 qualified applications through high-intent lead funnel
Target: Senior executives (35-60) who recognize need for upgraded strategic leadership capability
Key drivers: AI transformation, geopolitical complexity, sustainability demands
Budget efficiency: SGD 85,000 must deliver SGD 1,371 cost per application across 9 markets
Investment Logic
Market Allocation: Premium (SG/AU/JP) 55%, Growth (TW/TH/PH) 30%, Volume (IN/ID/VN) 15%
Channel Mix: LinkedIn 55%, Google Search 25%, Google Performance Max 20%
Rationale: LinkedIn for executive targeting precision, Search for active intent, Performance Max for scale
Audience Segmentation
Two distinct executive profiles
Target Personas
The Strategic Transformer

C-suite executives and business unit heads (40-55) managing P&L responsibility across multinational operations. Currently navigating AI adoption, geopolitical supply chain reconfiguration, or sustainability mandates without adequate strategic frameworks.

Decision drivers: Stanford-NUS faculty authority, case-based learning, immediate application to current challenges, board-level credibility, peer network across Asia-Pacific.
The Capability Builder

Senior directors and functional heads (35-50) positioned for C-suite advancement. Managing digital transformation initiatives or cross-functional strategy projects.

Decision drivers: Career ROI, leadership skill gaps (negotiation, governance, strategic foresight), employer sponsorship justification, promotion trajectory acceleration.
Psychological Barriers
Time scarcity: Executives resist commitment without clear ROI proof
Credibility threshold: Programme must demonstrate Stanford faculty caliber and peer quality
Application friction: Multi-step forms reduce conversion
Budget sensitivity: Premium markets prioritize quality, emerging markets need sponsorship justification
Conversion Funnel Architecture
Three-stage approach to qualified applications
Funnel Stages
Prospecting (60%): Capture attention via LinkedIn/Google. CTA: Download Brochure. Target: 620 downloads @ SGD 82.50
Retargeting (30%): Re-engage downloaders with social proof and urgency. CTA: Apply Now. Target: 10% conversion to 62 applications
Nurturing (10%): Email sequences with faculty profiles, alumni outcomes, ROI case studies. Target: 15% conversion rate
Messaging Structure
Tailored messaging for each funnel stage
Message Framework
Awareness: "AI. Geopolitics. Sustainability. Leadership Demands Have Changed." Stanford-NUS faculty expertise on navigating complexity.
Consideration: "Where Asia-Pacific's Strategic Leaders Develop Capability." 200+ executives. 85% apply learning immediately.
Conversion: "Applications Close [Date]." Limited intake. 15-minute application. 48-hour response.
Recommended Channel Mix
Three channels optimized for executive reach
LinkedIn (55% Budget)
Why: Executive targeting precision unmatched across platforms. Job title, seniority, industry filters deliver qualified audience. Professional context increases ad receptivity.
Role: Primary prospecting and retargeting channel. Drives brochure downloads and applications.
Formats: Traffic Ads, Lead Gen Ads, Conversation Ads support full-funnel engagement.
Risk Mitigation: High CPC (SGD 2.50-4.50) requires tight audience qualification and creative testing.
Google Search (25% Budget)

Why: Captures active intent from executives searching "executive leadership programme," "Cambridge NUS," "strategic leadership course." Responsive Search Ads allow message customization by keyword theme.
Role: Harvest high-intent searches. Drives applications directly and brochure downloads.
Risk Mitigation: Limited search volume across 9 markets requires expanded match types and competitor terms.
Google Performance Max (20% Budget)
Why: Automates placement across YouTube, Discovery, Gmail, Display to expand reach beyond Search. Machine learning optimizes toward application conversion.
Role: Scale brochure downloads through automated optimization. Retarget website visitors across Google properties.
Risk Mitigation: Requires strong asset diversity (headlines, images, videos) and conversion tracking discipline.
Campaign Flow
Integrated multi-channel user journey
Tactical Architecture
Prospecting: LinkedIn Traffic/Lead Gen Ads + Google Search/Performance Max → Landing Page → Brochure Download
Retargeting: LinkedIn Lead Gen/Conversation Ads + Google Retargeting → Application Page
Nurturing: 3-Email Sequence (Faculty → Alumni → Deadline) → Application
Media Plan & Expected Results
Performance projections across channels
Qualified Applications at SGD 1,371 CPA
Investment Summary
Full campaign scope and budget
